title: Wrexham Cathedral
text:
The Cathedral Church of Our Lady of Sorrows, also known as St Mary's Cathedral or Wrexham Cathedral, is a <a href="Roman%20Catholic">Roman Catholic</a> <a href="cathedral">cathedral</a> in <a href="Wrexham">Wrexham</a>, <a href="Wales">Wales</a>. It is the <a href="Chair%20%28official%29">seat</a> of the <a href="Bishop%20of%20Wrexham">Bishop of Wrexham</a>, and <a href="mother%20church">mother church</a> of the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Wrexham">Roman Catholic Diocese of Wrexham</a>.
History.
The cathedral was originally built as a <a href="parish%20church">parish church</a> in 1857. Its architect, <a href="E.%20W.%20Pugin">Edward Welby Pugin</a>, adopted a 14th-century <a href="English%20Gothic%20architecture%23Decorated%20Gothic">Decorated Gothic</a> style. The church replaced an earlier chapel, located in King Street, which by the 1850s was deemed insufficient for the growing congregation, and finance was provided by a local industrialist. Further additions to satisfy a still-growing congregation were made in the mid-20th century, in the form of the cloister and side chapel.
The church was designated a <a href="pro-cathedral">pro-cathedral</a> in 1898 upon the establishment of the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Menevia">Roman Catholic Diocese of Menevia</a>. It was consecrated on 7 November 1907.
The cathedral today.
Wrexham Cathedral is now a Grade II <a href="listed%20building">listed building</a>.
